I am a long time sins fan, and I really like what Stardock did here. 

A lot of games focus on adding features, but don't take the time to make sure that the game is performant enough to be playable, especially in the late game. Stellaris is an example of this: tremendously fun, but with serious late game slowdowns on large maps.

The problem is that making your game more performant takes time, and means shipping fewer features, at least at first. (units, maps, gameplay mechanics, etc)

With sins 2, they really took the time to make sure that the have a powerful, fast, multi-core game engine, and it shows. My 10 year old computer has never had any drops in performance, and the game looks beautiful. I especially love the animations when weapons fire impact shields.

For fans of sins1 who are into modding, this isn't just sins1 with better graphics. The old sins1 engine was 32 bit, and IIRC, single threaded. There was a very perceptible limit to how many mods you could run, and how many players and ships you could have. The new engine largely removes that limit. You can really go big.

Writing a performant, multi-threaded game engine is a very difficult thing to do well. For example, the Factorio devs found that without rewriting a significant chunk of their engine to use custom allocators, false sharing would actually cause the game to run slower multi-threaded than single threaded for it's main loop: https://www.factorio.com/blog/post/fff-215 . (Unfortunately, I don't have similar blog posts from Stardock explaining what exactly they multi-threaded or optimized, but it seems to work well in practice)

The developers were also very forward looking when it comes to modding. Sins 1 had a custom config you'd have to learn or parse to make changes. Without the right tooling, (which you probably didn't have), making large scale changes was hard. This is very common, with Stellaris also having it's own custom configuration language. I wound up writing my own parser just to do data extraction for modding it.

In sins2, all of the configs are just JSON files! There are excellent parsers available for JSON in just about every programming language, and lots of command line tools. It is so much easier to make edits, or write scripts to make the edits for you when a new version of Sins 2 comes out. The very readable and copy/pastable errors you get on game startup when you mess up are also very appreciated.

I really hope that now that they've added such a solid, fun, and playable base, the devs are well positioned to continue expanding this awesome game, and squashing any remaining bugs. Also very excited to see what the modding community does with it.

I didn't mind paying more to get the campaign. With the amount of passion that they put into the engine, I'm optimistic that it will be good.

(Sorry for picking on Stellaris a bit in this review. It's an awesome game as well.)

Sins of a Solar Empire II is a great modernization of the classic. While it doesn’t reinvent the formula with a ton of new features, it refines and streamlines nearly every part of the experience, making it the best way to play the series today.

The new research tree is a big highlight, it’s much more intuitive than before and opens up some genuinely interesting strategic paths. Planetary orbits also add a unique layer of planning, for example, you can no longer just build static defenses and forget about them, instead, you need to anticipate planetary movements and adjust your defenses accordingly such as remembering to rotate the structures around the planet. This subtle change really keeps the late game dynamic.

Modding support remains a strong aspect of the game. It’s easy to experiment with, and mods can dramatically extend replayability. The downside is that frequent updates can break mod compatibility, which is a bit frustrating for long-term players who rely on community content.

On the technical side, the visuals are gorgeous. Fleets look spectacular in large battles, and planets and environments have much more detail than in the original. Performance has been excellent on my high-end PC. I haven’t run into a single issue so far (excluding mods), even in large-scale engagements. It’s clear the engine has been optimized for modern hardware, which makes the experience smoother and more immersive.

Of course, the core gameplay loop is very familiar if you played the first Sins. This isn’t a radical sequel, more of a refinement, but the improvements in usability, visuals, and performance make it worthwhile.

Overall, Sins of a Solar Empire II feels like a confident step forward for the franchise. It’s a strong foundation, and I’m really looking forward to seeing how the game evolves with future DLCs and expansions.

Sins of a Solar Empire is one of those rare strategy games that successfully bridges the gap between real-time strategy (RTS) and 4X (explore, expand, exploit, exterminate) gameplay. Developed by Ironclad Games and published by Stardock, it's a space-based epic that delivers both the thrill of tactical battles and the depth of long-term empire planning and it does so with remarkable finesse.

From the very beginning, you're plunged into a beautifully realized galaxy, filled with rival factions, uncharted planets, and endless possibilities. The game's hybrid approach allows for massive real-time space battles with dozens of ships on-screen while simultaneously managing diplomacy, research, trade, and expansion. This makes every match feel like a living, breathing galactic saga.

One of the game's standout features is its scalability and pacing. Despite being real-time, the game never feels rushed. Players can pause and issue commands, making it accessible for those who are used to turn-based strategy games, while still offering enough speed and action to satisfy RTS veterans.

The three unique factions TEC, Advent, and Vasari each offer distinctive playstyles, technologies, and aesthetics. Whether you prefer brute economic force, psychic warfare, or high-tech hit-and-run tactics, there's a faction that will suit your strategy.

Graphically, while not bleeding-edge by modern standards, the game still holds up beautifully thanks to its clean UI, expansive space vistas, and well-designed ship models. Watching a fleet warp in and unleash hell on an enemy stronghold remains a visually satisfying experience.

Multiplayer and modding support have also given the game remarkable longevity. There’s a vibrant community around it, and countless mods  including total conversions  that breathe new life into the game long after release.

Verdict:
Sins of a Solar Empire is a genre-defining strategy game that rewards both tactical thinking and strategic planning. It’s epic in scale, deep in mechanics, and endlessly replayable. For anyone who dreams of commanding their own space-faring empire, this game is an absolute must-play.

First things first, this is a good game. A fully fledged well polished game. There is a single great innovation for the genre in this game, planets rotate. You thought you could build defensive structures on this choke hold of a planet and neglect all the rest behind it? Think again! That is truly awesome! There is an element of surprise and unpredictability in this element which keeps you on edge. The ships designs are awesome aesthetically and the fleet management is awesome! The game is easy to master. And that's with the good stuff about this game. 

Now I will try and provide some constructive criticism. 

-PREMISE. The game is simple. Just conquest stuff. Build your fleet and conquer. No real exploration no feeling of dread or mystery of exploring the vast unknown space. No random events, not even scripted events. Neutral factions are just some dumb AI that mostly work like space merchants. It's just you and some other players trying to figure out who is the bigger dictator. 

-RESEARCH. The research tree. Almost meaningless. For the the first few hours I was paying attention and then I was like "just queue all of them and I will figure out later the benefits". Research felt unimpactful because most of the times was some equipment that could be loaded on one of my capital ships. Guess what, you can only have so many capital ships because of supply limit so what is the point of having SO MANY equipment choices for your ships and the same goes for your planets too. You just figure out which items fit your playstyle and your empire's needs and go with them. 

-RESOURCES. Don't worry about resources. It's just two basic resources that can be found in every asteroid/planet. There are of course rare resources but you can build them later on. As for money you only need to worry about it the first few hours. Seriously once you figure out the basics and own about ten colonies you don't have to worry about resources anymore. Because no matter how vast your empire is THERE IS NO UPKEEP. So I can build TWO starbases in every single one of my colonies and not get taxed about it?

-SHIP/FLEET DESIGN. 4 types of frigates and 4 types of cruisers that I don't fully understand what their role in battle is. After a while some of the ships felt like more durable than others so I kept building them. Seriously there is no strategy involved or there is no sufficient explanation of it. Just don't waste resources in planet bombers, useless ships. They don't engage in any way in fights, your fleet is getting obliterated and they sit back relaxed bombing the planet.

I have not seen such cheating by the AI in all my life. I had a fully upgraded fleet at 2000. Yet the AI blew through my fleet with no problem. I would not recommend this game to anyone. Unless you are a glutton for punishment,

This is somewhat tough, as on paper in a mechanical sense, Sins of a Solar Empire 2 is a GOOD sequel. It follows the design philosophy that a sequel should be more of what you like, but iterated upon. Planet management has a deeper scale to it, fleet compositions are less spammy, and faction differences (Aside from the loyalist/rebel unique techs) are more complex.

Controlling and managing multiple fleets feels more streamlined and less granular without losing complexity, and early game exploration is heavily rewarded. Queuing researches and build orders is easily done and altered. It is a GOOD sequel. If you liked Sins 1, you will like Sins 2. 

However, what is a terrible shame and an absolute travesty is the sheer amount of AI generated images in the game, and something I cannot condone supporting. Especially when the first game had so much charm in it's programmer art and colored concepts.

Once noticed- it's impossible to look past. At first the Balenciaga stare on some of the portraits- then that odd uniform light shading. The constant tilt shift on anything that's supposed to look granular. Odd, in-congruent positioning and posing in images where figures are supposed to be interacting with each other. Figures staring at the camera and screaming. That telltale 'figure standing in front of a bulbous space ship' that doesn't match the design of the rest of the game.

The portraits you select when in the set up lobby have lost all of their unique charm. Sure- there's more of them, but what's the point when they all look vaguely the same? Thirty nearly identical portraits will never be better than 5 filled with personality. Even the in loading screen 'ads' for upcoming DLC's have a clearly AI generated figure within it. (Look at the eyes of the green eyed woman in the paths to power DLC banner.)

The UI is too clean, some of the buttons do not look like buttons. It is serviceable, but lacks the gritty charm the original had. The steam page states that: "This game used AI to help quickly iterate through designs for some UI elements using our own artwork as a baseline. AI is also used to help translate the game."

And this feels like a lie. The UI design does not feel iterative- and the amount of AI images used when you supposedly have an artist on payroll just screams 'We only wanted to pay them for a quarter of the work we wanted done.' 
If you have an artist, you have an artist. And even then, quirky programmer art will always be preferable to soulless AI generations.

One also has to wonder if some of this AI usage affected the visual designs of the ships themselves. Why did the Advent lose nearly all of their nautical theme?
(The hangar defenses- for instance, are now just wedges, rather than evocative of sea shells.)
Why did the Vasari ships lose their insectile appearance?
Why do the turrets on many of the TEC ships look like they were tacked on as an afterthought?

Were these conscious decisions from a person, or- did an AI simply smooth out the edges without understanding why those notions were present?

It's questioning like this that makes it hard to recommend. It looks bad, feels bad, and speaks to poor business decisions.

Similar to the original, SOASE2 struggles from a combination of scale, interface, and time-sensitive design constraints. Unlike the original, the use of Generative AI to create and prototype the interfaces definitely damaged this game so severely that I cannot in good faith recommend it to anyone. Even fans of SOASE1.

The single most interesting addition is the Orbit mechanic, a feature the original direly needed where-in planets move dynamically along a rail, changing their possible Phase Lane connections. A mod that adds this feature to the original game would basically make this game pointless. An utter waste of potential, the new tech tree is completely noisy beyond reckoning and the interface just... I can't explain it. You will not be able to find the things you need.

SOASE1 had a challenge or three to its scale specific to not always being able to figure out which freaking identical asteroid was under attack. Changes to the Tactical and Logistics slots system have made some differences to the fine balance of your first dozen planets, but this game is at its absolute weakest when player count and planet count starts getting too high. 2v2 or 4-way FFA probably is the best this game gets, the smaller the map the better so-as to force conflict before everyone is running into late-game balance issues.

Like the first game, Advent have substantial global disadvantages, only alleviated through their unique faction mechanic, the second new idea this game had. TEC has the old trade system but it's even less compelling than making a big trade line running across the galaxy, Advent have a spell and psychic power system that makes their starbases and capships stronger, and Vasari have the lamest passive bonus system possible for their faction. These faction systems like the orbit mechanics could be put into the old game, and this game would not need to exist.

There's some new space ships, some utterly unnecessary redesigns of virtually all of the old craft, and broadly speaking the UI damage just utterly destroys the game's once-decent fleet management options. The new Fleet system lets you build a titanic kinda-manageable mass of ships that rally to the node the fleet 'leader' is at (usually a cap ship or titan), but it doesn't let you set something like a Quota per-unit for battles that will come with attrition. As mentioned, the game's later phases are kind of just miserable grinding conflicts and the new neutral faction system honestly just isn't as cool as the old one which let you bumble into neutral planets with defenses to make initial expansion more challenging.

Now it's more like, you wipe out all of the neutral ships and claim your half of the galaxy within 15-30 minutes using a handful of frigates and your free cap ship. You couldn't do that in the past very easily, and that sort of blitz and streamlining steps done throughout contradict the awful menu design and frankly deplorable tech-tree which could have been trimmed to fit on the freaking screen. Just play the original, actual humans designed it, and I frankly don't think that happened with this one.

The steam page states that: "This game used AI to help quickly iterate through designs for some UI elements using our own artwork as a baseline. AI is also used to help translate the game."

And this feels like a lie. The UI design does not feel iterative- and the amount of AI images used when you supposedly have an artist on payroll just screams 'We only wanted to pay them for a quarter of the work we wanted done.' 
If you have an artist, you have an artist. And even then, quirky programmer art will always be preferable to soulless AI generations.

One also has to wonder if some of this AI usage affected the visual designs of the ships themselves. Why did the Advent lose nearly all of their nautical theme?
(The hangar defenses- for instance, are now just wedges, rather than evocative of sea shells.)
Why did the Vasari ships lose their insectile appearance?
Why do the turrets on many of the TEC ships look like they were tacked on as an afterthought?

Were these conscious decisions from a person, or- did an AI simply smooth out the edges without understanding why those notions were present?

It's questioning like this that makes it hard to recommend. It looks bad, feels bad, and speaks to poor business decisions.

Similar to the original, SOASE2 struggles from a combination of scale, interface, and time-sensitive design constraints. Unlike the original, the use of Generative AI to create and prototype the interfaces definitely damaged this game so severely that I cannot in good faith recommend it to anyone. Even fans of SOASE1.

The single most interesting addition is the Orbit mechanic, a feature the original direly needed where-in planets move dynamically along a rail, changing their possible Phase Lane connections. A mod that adds this feature to the original game would basically make this game pointless. An utter waste of potential, the new tech tree is completely noisy beyond reckoning and the interface just... I can't explain it. You will not be able to find the things you need.

SOASE1 had a challenge or three to its scale specific to not always being able to figure out which freaking identical asteroid was under attack. Changes to the Tactical and Logistics slots system have made some differences to the fine balance of your first dozen planets, but this game is at its absolute weakest when player count and planet count starts getting too high. 2v2 or 4-way FFA probably is the best this game gets, the smaller the map the better so-as to force conflict before everyone is running into late-game balance issues.

Like the first game, Advent have substantial global disadvantages, only alleviated through their unique faction mechanic, the second new idea this game had. TEC has the old trade system but it's even less compelling than making a big trade line running across the galaxy, Advent have a spell and psychic power system that makes their starbases and capships stronger, and Vasari have the lamest passive bonus system possible for their faction. These faction systems like the orbit mechanics could be put into the old game, and this game would not need to exist.

There's some new space ships, some utterly unnecessary redesigns of virtually all of the old craft, and broadly speaking the UI damage just utterly destroys the game's once-decent fleet management options. The new Fleet system lets you build a titanic kinda-manageable mass of ships that rally to the node the fleet 'leader' is at (usually a cap ship or titan), but it doesn't let you set something like a Quota per-unit for battles that will come with attrition. As mentioned, the game's later phases are kind of just miserable grinding conflicts and the new neutral faction system honestly just isn't as cool as the old one which let you bumble into neutral planets with defenses to make initial expansion more challenging.

Now it's more like, you wipe out all of the neutral ships and claim your half of the galaxy within 15-30 minutes using a handful of frigates and your free cap ship. You couldn't do that in the past very easily, and that sort of blitz and streamlining steps done throughout contradict the awful menu design and frankly deplorable tech-tree which could have been trimmed to fit on the freaking screen. Just play the original, actual humans designed it, and I frankly don't think that happened with this one.

Mechanically, this game is amazing. The "bones" of the economy, fleets, leveling up capital ships, research, equipping items to customize your ships and planets are all fantastic, and make up 50% of what could have been a masterpiece. Aside from that, your captains and the opposing empires have zero personality, aside from a few generic voice-over sound bites. There is no story, no random events to pull you into an immersive experience. I was just thinking about Stellaris, and how you'd randomly get these popups about your scientists finding a mummified pilot in a derelict ship, which you could salvage or research. Those little moments and stories are what gave it so much life, whereas this is just a "colonize planet and then zerg-rush the next system simulator." I've played for 11 hours and I feel like I've seen the whole thing. With all that said, if you can get it on a deep discount, then it's worth it.
